content.title: Pleural Effusion
content.summary: Pleural effusion is accumulation of fluid in the pleural space. Classification as transudative (systemic factors) vs exudative (local pleural disease) using Light's criteria guides etiology and management. Thoracentesis is diagnostic and therapeutic. Empyema and complicated parapneumonic effusions require drainage.
key_points: Light's criteria distinguish exudate from transudate (any 1 of 3 criteria = exudate)
Transudates: heart failure, cirrhosis, nephrotic syndrome (treat underlying cause)
Exudates: infection, malignancy, PE, rheumatologic disease (investigate cause)
Thoracentesis indicated for new effusions ≥10mm on decubitus or US
Complicated parapneumonic effusion and empyema require drainage
Malignant effusions: consider indwelling pleural catheter or pleurodesis
content.statement: Pleural effusion diagnosis requires differentiation of transudates (systemic causes) from exudates (local pleural disease) using Light's criteria, followed by targeted workup and management including thoracentesis and drainage when indicated.

explanation.intuition: The pleural space normally has just a thin film of fluid for lubrication. Excess fluid accumulates either because systemic pressures push fluid in (transudate - like water overflowing from a full bathtub) or because the pleura itself is diseased and leaking protein-rich fluid (exudate - like a wound oozing).
explanation.key_insight: Light's criteria are sensitive (~98%) but can misclassify transudates as exudates in diuretic-treated heart failure patients. If the fluid meets exudate criteria but clinically appears to be heart failure, check the serum-effusion albumin gradient (>1.2 g/dL = transudate) or serum-effusion protein gradient (>3.1 g/dL = transudate).
explanation.technical_details: Light's criteria: Pleural fluid protein/serum protein >0.5, OR pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH >0.6, OR pleural fluid LDH > 2/3 upper limit of normal serum LDH. Meeting any ONE criterion classifies as exudate.

definitions_glossary.pleural_effusion: Abnormal accumulation of fluid in the pleural space
definitions_glossary.transudate: Low-protein fluid from systemic factors (increased hydrostatic or decreased oncotic pressure)
definitions_glossary.exudate: High-protein fluid from pleural inflammation, infection, or malignancy
definitions_glossary.Light_criteria: Three laboratory criteria to differentiate exudate from transudate
definitions_glossary.thoracentesis: Needle aspiration of pleural fluid for diagnosis and/or symptom relief
definitions_glossary.parapneumonic_effusion: Pleural fluid associated with pneumonia; may be uncomplicated or complicated
definitions_glossary.complicated_parapneumonic: Infected effusion requiring drainage; pH <7.2, glucose <60, positive culture
definitions_glossary.empyema: Frank pus in pleural space; requires drainage
definitions_glossary.malignant_effusion: Effusion from pleural metastases or mesothelioma; often recurrent
definitions_glossary.pleurodesis: Chemical sclerosis of pleural space to prevent fluid recurrence (talc, doxycycline)
definitions_glossary.indwelling_pleural_catheter: IPC; tunneled catheter for outpatient drainage of recurrent effusions
definitions_glossary.loculated_effusion: Effusion divided by fibrin strands; may need fibrinolytics or VATS

pathophysiology.mechanism: Imbalance between pleural fluid production and absorption

transudative_causes.heart_failure: Most common cause of transudative effusion; often bilateral
transudative_causes.atelectasis: Decreased intrapleural pressure draws fluid in

exudative_causes.malignancy: Lung cancer, breast cancer, lymphoma, mesothelioma
exudative_causes.pulmonary_embolism: Exudate from pleural inflammation; often bloody
exudative_causes.rheumatologic: RA, lupus (check pleural fluid ANA, RF, complement)

clinical_presentation: Dyspnea (correlates with effusion size and rate of accumulation)
Decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion

imaging.CXR: Blunting of costophrenic angle (>200 mL); meniscus sign
imaging.lateral_decubitus: Free-flowing if layers ≥10mm; guides thoracentesis safety
imaging.ultrasound: Gold standard for guiding thoracentesis; detects loculations
imaging.CT: Evaluates underlying lung, pleural enhancement (empyema), masses

Light_criteria.definition: Exudate if ANY ONE of these is met:
criteria: Pleural fluid LDH > 2/3 upper limit of normal serum LDH

additional_tests.pH: <7.2 suggests complicated parapneumonic or empyema (needs drainage)
additional_tests.glucose: <60 mg/dL in complicated effusion, RA, malignancy, TB
additional_tests.cytology: 60-90% sensitive for malignancy (higher with repeat samples)
additional_tests.adenosine_deaminase: ADA >40-70 U/L suggests TB in high-prevalence areas

transudative.approach: Treat underlying cause (diuretics for HF, TIPS for hepatic hydrothorax)
transudative.therapeutic_thoracentesis: For symptomatic relief if large (≤1.5 L at a time)

complicated_parapneumonic_empyema.fibrinolytics: tPA + DNase for loculated effusions (MIST2 trial)
complicated_parapneumonic_empyema.surgery: VATS decortication if fibrinolytics fail or organized empyema

options: Indwelling pleural catheter (IPC) - preferred for most
Talc pleurodesis via chest tube or thoracoscopy
Serial therapeutic thoracentesis if limited life expectancy

definition.@value: Abnormal accumulation of fluid in the pleural space, classified as transudative or exudative based on Light's criteria

scopeNote.@value: Covers classification, Light's criteria, thoracentesis findings, and management of various etiologies

medicalCode.description: Pleural effusion in other conditions classified elsewhere

learning_objectives: Apply Light's criteria to classify pleural effusions
Identify common causes of transudative vs exudative effusions
Interpret thoracentesis results including pH, glucose, and cell counts
Recognize indications for chest tube drainage in parapneumonic effusions
Compare management options for malignant effusions
clinical_pearls: Light's criteria: ANY 1 of 3 met = exudate
pH <7.2 in parapneumonic effusion = needs drainage (don't wait for culture)
Bilateral effusions are usually transudative (heart failure) - often don't need thoracentesis
Lymphocyte-predominant exudate = think TB or malignancy
IPC is now preferred over pleurodesis for many malignant effusions
common_misconceptions: All effusions need thoracentesis - bilateral small transudates often don't
Empyema always shows positive cultures - 40% are culture-negative
Pleurodesis is best for malignant effusions - IPC often preferred now

evidence.confidence_rationale: Based on Light's original criteria and subsequent validation studies

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed.
